properties.name: US Fish & Wildlife Service

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: Panoche Valley Solar, LLC is proposing to construct a 247 megawatt photovoltaic solar generating facility in eastern unincorporated San Benito County, California. The proposed project site contains ephemeral drainages that have been determined to be jurisdictional waters of the U.S. Construction requires a Department of the Army permit from the US Army Corps of Engineers to discharge fill material into these waters, in accordance with Section 404 of the Clean Water Act. The US Army Corps of Engineers made a preliminary determination that the proposed project constitutes a major federal action that may result in significant impacts on the environment, and that the preparation of an environmental impact statement was required.

properties.content: The Draft EIS was distributed for public review and comment from September 11, 2015 to October 26, 2015. This Final EIS responds to the substantive comments received on the Draft EIS during the public review and comment period.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.location: Panoche Valley, San Benito County, California
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project aims to construct a utility-scale, solar PV energy generating facility in the Panoche Valley region. The project is intended to help California meet its mandatory Renewable Portfolio Standard, which requires 33 percent of electricity to come from renewable sources by 2020.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The Final Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility evaluates various alternatives including the No Action Alternative, Alternative A (Applicant's Proposed Project Preferred Alternative), Alternative B (On-site Alternative), and Alternative C (Off-site Alternative, Westlands CREZ). The report assesses environmental impacts, particularly on aesthetics, with findings that all cumulative impacts would be less than significant due to measures like the use of dulled finishes and colors, maintenance of visual quality, and avoidance of tower construction in non-developed areas.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The Final Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility evaluates various alternatives including No Action, No USACE Permit, Alternative A (Proposed Project), Alternative B (On-site Alternative), and Alternative C (Off-site Alternative, Westlands CREZ). The analysis considers the impacts on greenhouse gas emissions, vegetation removal, carbon sequestration, and the effects of telecommunication upgrades by PG&E. The results show that all alternatives would have less than significant cumulative environmental impacts.

Legal measures and mitigation efforts were mandated as part of the approval process.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The project site has been used for cattle grazing and previously for crop production over the past forty years. The proposed project involves the installation of ground-mounted PV modules, an underground electrical system, and related infrastructure to deliver power to the state electrical grid.
Project.capacity: Over one million PV panels installed on approximately 1,529 acres with a maximum height of 10 feet.
Project.technology: Ground-mounted PV modules with single-axis tracker system, panels oriented to maximize solar efficiency, and direct-driven steel support structures.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves the installation of solar arrays, support infrastructure including roads, substation, switching station, O&M building, and other features. The project will have both permanent and temporary impact areas.
Project.capacity: Output potentially up to 245.83 MW (145 1.67-MW blocks and 6 0.83-MW blocks)
Project.technology: Photovoltaic solar panels with inverters to convert DC to AC energy

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves the installation of high-efficiency photovoltaic (PV) panels. The project footprint includes a 20-foot-wide perimeter road for maintenance and emergency response, as well as transportation corridors. The PV panels generate direct current electricity, which is collected and converted to alternating current before being transmitted to a proposed substation.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.location: Panoche Valley, west side of Little Panoche Road
properties.summary: The project involves the construction of a substation and switching station north of the existing PG&E transmission line. The facilities will transform medium-voltage power from the project’s delivery system to the existing PG&E 230 kV transmission line.
properties.technology: Solar, electrical transformers, switchgear, SCADA equipment

properties.fullName: Pacific Gas and Electric Company

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves the construction and operation of solar energy infrastructure, including an O&M building, perimeter and internal access roads, and transportation corridors. Safety measures and local code compliance are emphasized.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The document section appears to pertain to the project description and alternatives for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: Detailed in Figure 2-10 of the Final Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), Section 2 - Project Description and Alternatives

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves implementing a stormwater pollution prevention plan (SWPPP) with various best management practices (BMPs) to minimize erosion and runoff during construction and operation of the project. Structural BMPs and a stormwater control basin will mitigate potential stormwater contamination and runoff from the project’s impervious surfaces. Vegetation management involving indigenous species and sheep grazing will be employed to maintain the area under solar panels. Utilities, including electrical and water services, will be arranged through local power grids, on-site wells, and portable facilities.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The project involves routing fiber and/or copper through directional boring for the installation of underground conduit, trenching, and the use of existing facilities to bring services to the project site. Water use during construction is also detailed.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility entails the development of temporary ponds for water needs during construction, vegetation management via species exclusion fencing, construction of a septic tank and leach field near the O&M building, and erosion control using native plant stock in disturbed areas.
properties.technology: Solar energy, water wells, septic system

properties.name: San Benito County
properties.fullName: San Benito County

summary.default: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves the construction of solar panels in a clockwise progression around the site over approximately 18 months. It includes the implementation of various safety measures and will have fire suppression systems in place. Emergency response plans will be developed in coordination with relevant local, state, and federal agencies.

default.name: San Benito County Public Health Department
default.fullName: San Benito County Public Health Department

summary.value: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves commissioning and maintenance of PV arrays without night-time ground-disturbing activities. Site prep includes biological surveys and grading primarily for panels on slopes greater than three percent, with 358 acres to be graded. Construction runs from sunrise to sunset; no cubic yards of export expected.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves substantial construction traffic, estimated daily trips, and the delivery of various construction materials.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves the delivery of various project components via different types of trucks. Materials will be delivered throughout construction, and much of the heavy construction equipment will remain on-site for the duration of construction.

summary.default: The project involves the construction and operation of a solar facility in Panoche Valley, California. It includes several types of construction vehicles and equipment for the installation of photovoltaic panels. The project aims to ensure grid reliability and has undergone multiple interconnection studies conducted by CAISO and PG&E.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project is a solar power project that includes installation of interconnection facilities and network upgrades to transfer electricity to the PG&E Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kV transmission line. The project has agreements in place for power purchase and generator interconnection.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility is expected to be fully operational by the end of 2016 and would operate for at least 30 years. The facility will have a control room for monitoring system status, forecasting, and operational planning. Security measures include 24-hour on-site patrols, fencing, and surveillance cameras. Maintenance will involve regular inspections and potential panel washing, with water use allocated for sanitary facilities, fire suppression, and livestock grazing.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The project involves the operation and maintenance (O&M) activities of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, including water requirements, lighting, and security measures. It also includes measures to reduce environmental impacts as part of the EIR process.
Project.capacity: 2.84 acre‐feet of water annually for O&M, with additional water for fire suppression and livestock watering.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: A solar facility project with several Applicant Proposed Measures (APMs) to mitigate environmental and visual impacts during construction and operation.

properties.name: US Fish and Wildlife Service

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The project involves the implementation of multiple environmental protection measures (APMs) to mitigate impacts on local wildlife, including the Blunt-Nosed Leopard Lizard, Giant Kangaroo Rat, and San Joaquin Kit Fox.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The project involves the development of a solar facility in Panoche Valley. Various Applicant Proposed Measures (APMs) are implemented to safeguard environmental, cultural, geological, and noise standards. These measures also address hazards, hazardous materials, and population housing concerns.

properties.id: Panoche Valley Solar Facility Final EIS
properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project includes a series of Applicant Proposed Measures (APMs) and Environmental Impact Report (EIR) Mitigation Measures aimed at addressing public services and facilities, water resources, aesthetics, and agriculture. These measures include repairing damages, maintaining the site, reducing environmental impacts, and implementing various restoration and conservation plans.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The project description includes various mitigation measures focused on land use, air quality, biological resources, and water resources to minimize environmental impacts. Key measures include reducing fugitive dust, implementing weed control and grazing plans, creating conservation easements, monitoring groundwater, and protecting sensitive species through pre-construction surveys.

properties.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project includes various mitigation measures to protect local wildlife before and during construction.

PG&E and CAISO are responsible for ensuring the necessary telecommunication upgrades for grid reliability.

summary.default: PG&E proposes to install new optical ground wire (OPGW) along 17 miles of its existing Panoche-Moss Landing 230 kV transmission line, and use All-Dielectric Self-Supporting (ADSS) fiber in areas to provide telecommunications services between electrical substations, while requiring minimal modification to existing transmission towers.

technology.default: Optical Ground Wire (OPGW), All-Dielectric Self-Supporting (ADSS) fiber, Power Line Carrier (PLC), leased line systems

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The project involves the installation of temporary guard structures and crossings of public roadways or existing transmission or distribution lines. Temporary structures with nets and wooden poles will be installed at several crossings to prevent tools or materials from falling. No grading or vegetation removal is anticipated. Additionally, the project includes the crossing of 500 kV lines with ADSS fiber optic cable, which involves the replacement of twelve wood poles and trenching activities.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: PG&E proposes secondary telecommunication upgrades including a microwave communication system for redundancy, involving new towers at existing switch station and Helm Substation.

properties.name: Westlands Solar Park
properties.location: California’s Central Valley, encompassing portions of San Benito, Merced, Madera, Fresno, and Kings County
properties.summary: The project involves developing a solar photovoltaic energy-generating facility with a capacity of approximately 247 MW on leased lands within the Westlands Competitive Renewable Energy Zone (CREZ). It aims to build solar projects that are 200 MW or larger as part of commercial development by Westside Holdings.

properties.name: Pacific Gas and Electric

properties.name: Westlands CREZ Alternative
properties.summary: A 247 MW PV solar facility constructed on a 2,500-acre site within the Westlands CREZ. No conditional use permitting or master planning has been performed by Fresno or Kings County. The alternative does not propose transmission infrastructure or county mitigation measures.

properties.name: United States Army Corps of Engineers

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The project aims to provide 247 MW of solar power. An alternative access road plan proposed by CDFW was rejected by the Hollister Fire Department due to insufficient emergency egress. Various alternative crossing technologies were evaluated but mostly eliminated from further consideration.

properties.name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
properties.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
properties.summary: The project involves ford and culvert crossings for jurisdictional streams, comprising Las Aguilas and Panoche Creeks, using methods such as cabled concrete block mattresses and multi-barreled concrete box culverts. However, alternatives were eliminated due to their lack of compatibility with emergency access requirements and higher impacts on waters of the U.S. Off-site locations including the Brownfield-Kettleman City site were also considered but eliminated.

properties.name: Panoche Valley Solar, LLC
properties.fullName: Panoche Valley Solar, LLC

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project and various alternatives were explored, including the Brownfield-Kettleman City site and the Moss Landing-Panoche site. These alternatives were analyzed in terms of their suitability for solar power output, potential environmental impacts, and land use considerations.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: This section of the project description and alternatives provides information on the Panoche Valley Solar Facility.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project explores various alternatives for solar development. The alternatives considered include the Panoche Ranch and Firebaugh sites, both of which were eliminated from detailed consideration due to various constraints such as site hydrological features, insufficient size, and unavailability for long-term sale or lease.

Organizations.name: United States Fish and Wildlife Service
Organizations.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.location: Panoche Valley, Western Fresno County, California
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility has been evaluated for its feasibility as a site for a 247 MW solar facility. The site includes prime farmland, creeks, and several canals, as well as potential wetlands. Special status species and transmission line proximity were also considered. However, the property is not available for lease or sale.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The project aims to construct a 247 MW solar facility. Various alternative renewable energy technologies such as wind, biomass, and geothermal were considered but not implemented. Distributed solar generation was evaluated but was deemed less feasible compared to utility-scale due to various technical and environmental considerations.

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.summary: The project aims to provide 247 MW of solar power. Alternative forms of renewable energy such as wind, biomass, and geothermal were not considered in detail. The project will employ PV solar technology as other solar technologies like concentrated solar power have greater or equal environmental impacts.

Organizations.name: United States Army Corps of Engineers
Organizations.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
Project.location: west-central portion of the Central Valley
Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility is a project aimed at constructing a 247 MW solar facility in the west-central portion of the Central Valley. The project was evaluated and considered crucial despite alternatives focused on conservation and demand-side management. These alternatives were deemed insufficient to meet the increasing energy demands due to population growth.
